contentSections.title: Crossing Roads Safely
contentSections.content: When crossing roads, there are important steps to follow. First, find a safe place to cross - a crossing, traffic lights, or a clear spot with good visibility. Stop at the edge of the road. Look left, look right, look left again. Listen for traffic you might not see. Wait until all traffic has stopped or passed. Walk, don't run, across the road. Keep looking as you cross. Holding an adult's hand when you're young helps keep you safe.

contentSections.title: Being Seen
contentSections.content: Drivers need to be able to see you to avoid hitting you. Wear bright colours during the day. At night or when it's dark, wear reflective gear that shines when lights hit it. Don't wear dark clothes at night. Stay where drivers can see you - not between parked cars or behind bushes. Make eye contact with drivers before crossing in front of them. If a driver doesn't see you, you're in danger.

contentSections.title: Safe Cycling
contentSections.content: When riding a bike, always wear a helmet. The helmet should fit properly - not too loose or too tight. Ride on the footpath if you're under 12 (and allowed in your state). Check your brakes work before riding. Use lights and reflectors when it's dark or hard to see. Always ride in control - not too fast. Watch for cars coming out of driveways. Don't ride while holding things that make it hard to steer.

contentSections.title: Safe on Public Transport
contentSections.content: On buses and trains, stay safe by following some simple rules. Wait away from the edge of the platform or road. Let people get off before you get on. Find a seat or hold on tight when standing. Keep your bag in a safe place so people don't trip. Stay seated while the bus or train is moving. Don't distract the driver. Follow any rules the driver tells you. Stay back from the doors until they're fully open.

remember.question: When crossing a road, which direction should you look first in Australia?

options.text: Right
options.feedback: In Australia where we drive on the left, traffic comes from the right when you first step out, so look left first.

options.text: Left
options.feedback: Correct! In Australia, traffic on your side of the road comes from your left, so look left first.

options.text: Up
options.feedback: Traffic comes from the sides, not from above. Look left first.

options.text: It doesn't matter
options.feedback: It does matter! In Australia, look left first, then right, then left again.

understand.question: Why should you wear bright or reflective clothing when walking near roads?

options.text: Because it looks cool
options.feedback: It's not about looks - it's about safety.

options.text: So drivers can see you and avoid hitting you
options.feedback: Correct! Being visible helps drivers see you in time to stop or avoid you.

options.text: Because it's the law
options.feedback: While some workplaces require it, for pedestrians it's about being seen for safety.

options.text: To keep you warm
options.feedback: Bright clothing is about visibility, not warmth.

apply.question: You're walking to school and come to a road with no crossing. What should you do?

options.text: Run across quickly between cars
options.feedback: Running is dangerous and gives you less time to see danger. Never rush across roads.

options.text: Find a clear spot where you can see both ways, stop, look left, right, left again, wait for traffic to clear, then walk across
options.feedback: Correct! This is the safe way to cross when there's no crossing.

options.text: Walk behind a parked car and step out
options.feedback: Drivers can't see you behind parked cars. Find a clear spot where you can see and be seen.

options.text: Walk until you find a crossing no matter how far
options.feedback: While crossings are ideal, you can cross safely at a clear spot following the correct procedure.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should explain this is not a good choice because helmets protect the head from serious injuries. A properly fitted helmet shouldn't be uncomfortable. Head injuries can be life-threatening or cause permanent damage. The law requires helmets in Australia. A moment of discomfort is worth protection.

relational.stem: Explain why looking left, then right, then left again helps keep you safe when crossing a road.
relational.modelResponse: Looking left first is important because in Australia cars drive on the left side, so traffic coming toward you will come from the left first. Looking right then checks for traffic coming the other way. Looking left again makes sure no car has come closer since your first look. This pattern catches traffic from both directions and gives you the most up-to-date information before you step onto the road.
relational.rubric: Explains the Australian driving context. Shows understanding of why looking multiple times in a pattern catches traffic from both directions. Demonstrates why the final look left updates information.

extendedAbstract.stem: Think about why road accidents are a leading cause of injury for young people. What could help make roads safer for children and teenagers?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Young people get injured on roads for several reasons: they may not judge car speed well, they might be distracted by phones or friends, and they're still learning safe habits. To make roads safer for young people, we could: have more safe crossings near schools and parks, teach road safety from a young age, design roads with slow zones where children are, have better footpaths and bike paths separated from traffic, and help young people understand how dangerous cars can be. Adults and communities have a responsibility to create safer environments, not just expect children to always be perfectly careful.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies factors contributing to youth road injuries. Suggests improvements at multiple levels (individual, infrastructure, community). Shows understanding that safety is a shared responsibility.

contentSections.title: Understanding Pedestrian Risks
contentSections.content: Pedestrians face several risks near roads. Distractions like phones, headphones, or talking to friends can make you miss important dangers. Crossing between parked cars means drivers can't see you. Assuming drivers have seen you is dangerous - always check. Rushing leads to poor decisions. At night or in bad weather, visibility is reduced for everyone. Understanding these risks helps you manage them by staying alert, choosing safe crossing spots, and never assuming a driver has seen you.

contentSections.title: Cycling Rules and Safety
contentSections.content: Cyclists follow road rules like other vehicles. In Australia, you must: always wear a properly fitted helmet, use front and rear lights at night, have a working bell, ride on the left side of the road (or on paths where allowed), give way to pedestrians on shared paths, and use hand signals when turning. You should also: wear bright or reflective clothing, maintain your bike (especially brakes), avoid riding next to trucks and buses (they have big blind spots), and never wear headphones while riding.

contentSections.title: What Drivers Can't See
contentSections.content: Understanding what drivers can and can't see helps you stay safe. Blind spots exist in every vehicle - areas the driver can't see even with mirrors. These are especially large for trucks and buses. Drivers can't see well in rain, fog, or glare. At night, you're nearly invisible without reflective gear or lights. Even attentive drivers have limited reaction time - they can't stop instantly. When drivers are distracted (looking at phone, GPS, or children), they see even less. Never assume a driver has seen you - make eye contact or wait until you're sure.

contentSections.title: Making Safe Transport Choices
contentSections.content: As you become more independent, you make more transport choices. Consider: Is it safe to walk this route? Do I have appropriate cycling gear? Is public transport available? Am I alert enough or too tired/distracted? Is it too dark without appropriate visibility gear? Would it be safer to get a lift? Good decisions consider the specific circumstances. What's safe in daylight might not be safe at night. What's safe when alert might not be safe when tired. Planning ahead helps you make safe choices.

remember.question: What are cycling lights and bell legally required for?

options.text: Looking cool
options.feedback: These are legal requirements for safety, not appearance.

options.text: Lights to see and be seen at night; bell to warn others
options.feedback: Correct! Lights help you see and be seen in low light, and bells warn pedestrians and others of your approach.

options.text: They're optional extras
options.feedback: Lights (at night) and bells are legal requirements in Australia.

options.text: To make the bike faster
options.feedback: Lights and bells are for safety, not speed.

understand.question: Why is it particularly dangerous to walk or cycle near trucks and buses?

options.text: Because they drive faster than cars
options.feedback: Speed isn't the main issue. Trucks and buses have significant blind spots.

options.text: Because they have large blind spots where drivers can't see pedestrians or cyclists
options.feedback: Correct! Large vehicles have significant blind spots on all sides. If you can't see the driver's mirrors, they can't see you.

options.text: Because their drivers are less skilled
options.feedback: Large vehicle drivers are often very skilled, but even skilled drivers can't see into blind spots.

options.text: Because they make too much noise
options.feedback: While they are loud, the main danger is the driver not being able to see you in their blind spots.

apply.question: You're cycling to a friend's house and it's starting to get dark. You don't have lights on your bike. What should you do?

options.text: Ride quickly so you get there before it's completely dark
options.feedback: Riding faster is more dangerous, not safer. You need proper equipment.

options.text: Wear bright clothes and ride anyway since lights aren't that important
options.feedback: Lights are legally required at night and are essential for visibility. Bright clothes alone aren't enough.

options.text: Walk your bike or find another way, like asking for a lift, since riding without lights is illegal and dangerous
options.feedback: Correct! Without lights, you're not visible to drivers and you're breaking the law. Choose a safer option.

options.text: Ride on the footpath instead of the road
options.feedback: Depending on your age and state, footpath riding may or may not be legal, but either way you still need lights at night.

analyse.question: Analyse why stopping distance increases in wet weather and how this affects pedestrian safety.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse the physics and implications. Wet roads are slippery, so tyres have less grip. This means cars take longer to stop - stopping distance can double in wet conditions. For pedestrians, this means: drivers may not be able to stop in time even if they see you; you need to give more space; crossing decisions that would be safe in dry weather might be dangerous in wet weather. Strong responses connect the physics to practical safety implications.
successCriteria: Explains why wet roads increase stopping distance
Identifies that stopping distance can double or more
Analyses implications for pedestrian safety
Connects to practical decision-making

evaluate.question: Evaluate whether it's safe to use headphones while walking along busy roads. Consider the benefits and risks.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate both sides. Risks: can't hear traffic, sirens, or warnings; more easily distracted; reduced awareness of surroundings. Benefits: entertainment, may be low-risk on quiet paths. Evaluation should conclude that headphones reduce safety, especially on busy roads. May suggest alternatives like using only one earphone at low volume on quieter routes. Strong responses show balanced consideration leading to a reasoned conclusion.
successCriteria: Identifies risks of wearing headphones near traffic
Considers any potential benefits or contexts
Makes a reasoned evaluation of overall safety
May suggest safer alternatives

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a comprehensive cycling safety checklist. Equipment: helmet fits properly, brakes work, tyres pumped, lights and reflectors, bell works, bright/reflective clothing. Route: knows the way, safest roads/paths, knows where traffic is busiest. Behaviour: leaves enough time (no rushing), stays alert, uses hand signals, follows road rules. Checklist should be practical and cover pre-ride, route, and riding behaviour.

Addresses route planning

multistructural.stem: List four things that are legally required when cycling in Australia.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four legal requirements for cycling are: 1) An approved helmet properly fitted and fastened, 2) A front white light at night, 3) A rear red light or reflector at night, 4) A working bell or horn.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four correct legal requirements. May include helmet, lights, reflectors, bell, or riding on correct side.

relational.stem: Explain how distractions affect both pedestrians and drivers, and why this creates a dangerous situation.
relational.modelResponse: When both pedestrians and drivers are distracted, danger multiplies. A distracted pedestrian might not look properly, assume cars will stop, or step out unexpectedly. A distracted driver might not see the pedestrian, react slowly, or not stop in time. Normally, if one party makes a mistake, the other might compensate - an alert driver might stop for a careless pedestrian, or an alert pedestrian might jump back from a dangerous driver. But when both are distracted, neither catches the other's mistake. This is why distraction is so dangerous - it removes the safety margin that alert road users provide.
relational.rubric: Explains how distractions affect both groups. Shows understanding of how safety depends on at least one party being alert. Identifies why mutual distraction is particularly dangerous.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how transport safety will change as electric vehicles become more common. What new challenges and opportunities might arise?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Electric vehicles create new safety challenges and opportunities. Challenges: EVs are very quiet, so pedestrians and cyclists may not hear them approaching; this is especially dangerous for people with vision impairments. EVs can accelerate quickly, potentially surprising pedestrians. Opportunities: EVs are being designed with better sensors and automatic emergency braking that could prevent collisions; some will alert pedestrians with sounds; data from sensors could identify dangerous locations. Autonomous EVs in the future could eliminate human driver error. However, a transition period where some cars are autonomous and some aren't could be confusing. Education will need to adapt - people will need to learn new habits for quiet vehicles while technology develops solutions.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies new safety challenges from EVs, particularly quietness. Recognises opportunities from technology. Shows sophisticated thinking about transition periods. Considers adaptation needs.

Extreme tiredness that reduces alertness and reaction time

contentSections.title: Analysing Transport Risks
contentSections.content: Different transport modes have different risk profiles. Pedestrian risks include distraction, limited visibility, and vulnerability to vehicles. Cyclist risks include sharing space with larger vehicles, balance/skill issues, and weather exposure. Passenger risks include driver behaviour and not wearing seatbelts. Analysing risks involves considering: the likelihood of an incident, the severity of potential outcomes, and what factors increase or decrease risk. Young people are over-represented in road statistics due to inexperience, risk-taking, peer influence, and distraction.

contentSections.title: Factors Affecting Driver Performance
contentSections.content: Many factors impair driving ability. Alcohol slows reaction time, reduces coordination, and impairs judgement - any alcohol affects driving. Drugs (including some medications) impair perception, reaction, and decision-making. Fatigue has similar effects to alcohol - driving tired is as dangerous as driving drunk. Distraction (phones, passengers, GPS, food) takes attention from the road - at 60km/h, looking at your phone for 2 seconds means travelling 33 metres blind. Speeding reduces time to react and massively increases crash severity. Emotions (anger, stress, excitement) affect decision-making. Understanding these factors prepares you to be a safer future driver.

contentSections.title: Safe System Approach
contentSections.content: Australia uses a 'Safe System' approach to road safety. It recognises that humans make mistakes, so the system should be designed so mistakes don't result in death or serious injury. The four pillars are: Safe Roads (designed to reduce crash severity), Safe Speeds (appropriate for the road and conditions), Safe Vehicles (with safety features), and Safe People (educated and making safe choices). This approach shares responsibility between road designers, vehicle manufacturers, law enforcement, and road users. It's a shift from just blaming individuals for crashes to creating a system that protects people.

contentSections.title: Preparing to Drive
contentSections.content: Though driving is years away, preparation starts now. Understanding road dynamics as a pedestrian and cyclist builds knowledge. Victoria's Graduated Licensing System (GLS) introduces driving gradually: learner phase (120 hours supervised), P1 phase (high restrictions), P2 phase (moderate restrictions), then full licence. This works because new drivers need experience in progressively challenging situations. Understanding why restrictions exist (passengers, night driving, speed) helps you comply when you get there. Attitudes to risk, drugs, and distraction are formed before you drive.

apply.question: You're getting a lift home from a party with a friend who you suspect has been drinking. Apply your knowledge to decide what to do.

analyse.question: Analyse why young drivers (17-25) are significantly over-represented in road crash statistics.

Night driving: more common for social activities. Alcohol/drugs: social contexts increase exposure. Overconfidence: underestimate risks as skills develop. Strong responses connect these factors rather than just listing them.

multistructural.modelResponse: The four phases are: 1) Learner permit (supervised driving, 120 hours required), 2) P1 licence (red P-plates, strictest restrictions), 3) P2 licence (green P-plates, moderate restrictions), 4) Full licence (no P-plate restrictions).

relational.stem: Explain how the Safe System approach is different from just blaming individual drivers for crashes.
relational.modelResponse: The Safe System approach recognises that humans are imperfect and will make mistakes. Instead of just blaming individuals when crashes happen, it asks: how can we design roads, vehicles, speeds, and systems so that mistakes don't result in death or serious injury? For example, a roundabout can be designed so that even if someone enters too fast, they can't crash at fatal speeds. Flexible barriers can absorb impact. Speed limits can match what's survivable for the road type. This shares responsibility among road designers, vehicle manufacturers, enforcement, and users. It's a shift from 'bad driver caused crash' to 'how could the system have prevented fatal consequences?'
relational.rubric: Explains the Safe System's acceptance of human error. Shows how system design can compensate. Identifies shared responsibility. Contrasts with individual blame approach.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how autonomous (self-driving) vehicles might change road safety for pedestrians and cyclists. What benefits and challenges might arise?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Autonomous vehicles could transform pedestrian and cyclist safety. Benefits: AVs don't get distracted, tired, drunk, or emotional - they're always paying attention. They have 360-degree sensors that don't have human blind spots. They could predict and respond to pedestrians and cyclists more consistently. They communicate with each other to coordinate. This could dramatically reduce crashes caused by human driver error. Challenges: The technology isn't perfect and may struggle with unusual situations. During transition, mixed traffic of AVs and human drivers creates complexity. AVs may be too cautious (stopping for every potential pedestrian) or too aggressive. Pedestrians might become careless, assuming AVs will stop. Ethical dilemmas arise about programming crash responses. Cyclists and pedestrians need to trust AVs, which takes time. Technology could fail. The transition period might be more dangerous before it gets safer.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies multiple potential benefits. Analyses realistic challenges, especially during transition. Shows sophisticated understanding of human-technology interaction. Considers how behaviours might change.

contentSections.title: Analysing Road Safety Data
contentSections.content: Australia loses over 1,100 people to road crashes annually, with many more seriously injured. Analysing data reveals patterns: rural roads have higher fatality rates per distance; young people are over-represented; single-vehicle crashes (often fatigue-related) are common on rural roads; speed is a factor in most fatal crashes; pedestrian deaths are rising in some areas. Data is reported per population, per registered vehicle, and per distance travelled - each measure tells different stories. Understanding data helps identify priorities. Victoria's road toll has declined over decades through interventions like seatbelt laws, drink-driving enforcement, and safer vehicles, but progress has stalled.

contentSections.title: Evaluating Road Safety Policies
contentSections.content: Different policies address different aspects of the Safe System. Speed management includes speed limits, speed cameras, point-to-point enforcement, and road design. Impairment prevention includes drink-driving limits, drug testing, and fatigue rules for commercial drivers. GLS restrictions limit exposure of new drivers to high-risk situations. Infrastructure improvements include barriers, roundabouts, and safe road design. Vehicle standards require safety features. Evaluating policies requires considering: effectiveness evidence, cost-benefit, enforcement feasibility, public acceptance, and equity (who benefits and who bears costs).

contentSections.title: Protecting Vulnerable Road Users
contentSections.content: Pedestrians, cyclists, and motorcyclists are 'vulnerable' because they lack the protection of vehicle cabins. Their safety requires specific attention. Infrastructure solutions include separated bike lanes, pedestrian crossings, lower speed limits in areas of conflict. Vehicle solutions include vulnerable road user detection systems, underrun protection on trucks. Behaviour change includes public awareness campaigns and driver education about blind spots. As cities seek to increase walking and cycling (for health and environmental benefits), protecting these modes becomes essential for achieving mode shift.

contentSections.title: Advocacy for Safer Transport
contentSections.content: Young people can advocate for road safety improvements. This might involve: identifying local safety issues (dangerous intersections, lack of crossings or bike paths), gathering data on near-misses or community concerns, understanding what solutions might work, engaging with local councils or VicRoads, building community support, and persisting through decision-making processes. Effective advocacy is informed (based on evidence), constructive (proposing solutions), and strategic (understanding how decisions are made). Youth voice is powerful in road safety because young people are disproportionately affected.

remember.question: What is Vision Zero in road safety?

options.text: A type of driver vision test
options.feedback: Vision Zero refers to a policy approach, not vision testing.

options.text: A road safety policy that sets a target of zero road deaths and serious injuries
options.feedback: Correct! Vision Zero started in Sweden and sets an ethical position that no death on roads is acceptable.

options.text: Cars that have zero emissions
options.feedback: Vision Zero is about eliminating deaths, not emissions.

options.text: Roads with no speed limits
options.feedback: Actually, Vision Zero often involves lower speed limits where vulnerable road users are present.

understand.question: Why might road deaths per distance travelled be a more useful measure than total deaths?

options.text: Because it's easier to calculate
options.feedback: It's actually more complex to calculate, but provides better insights.

options.text: Because it accounts for how much people are travelling, allowing fairer comparison between different times and places
options.feedback: Correct! If people travel twice as far but deaths only increase slightly, roads are actually getting safer per trip.

options.text: Because politicians prefer it
options.feedback: The measure is preferred because it's more meaningful, not for political reasons.

options.text: Because it always shows smaller numbers
options.feedback: The number isn't always smaller - it's about what the number means.

apply.question: A local intersection has had several pedestrian injuries. Apply the Safe System approach to suggest improvements addressing each pillar.

options.text: Just put up a 'Be Careful' sign
options.feedback: This only addresses Safe People, not the full Safe System.

options.text: Safe Roads: improve crossing design; Safe Speeds: lower speed limit; Safe Vehicles: require detection systems; Safe People: awareness campaign
options.feedback: Correct! This applies all four pillars to create multiple layers of protection.

options.text: Tell pedestrians to cross somewhere else
options.feedback: This puts all responsibility on pedestrians rather than applying system solutions.

options.text: Install a speed camera
options.feedback: This addresses Safe Speeds/People but not Safe Roads or Vehicles.

analyse.question: Analyse why pedestrian and cyclist deaths have been stable or increasing in some areas while overall road deaths have decreased.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple factors. Car occupant deaths have decreased through better vehicle safety, but vulnerable users don't benefit from vehicle crashworthiness. Increased walking/cycling (mode shift) increases exposure. Distraction affects both drivers and pedestrians. Vehicle design (higher, heavier SUVs) increases pedestrian injury severity. Investment may have prioritised car occupant safety over vulnerable users. Some areas have inadequate infrastructure for walking/cycling. Strong responses connect these factors to show systemic patterns.
successCriteria: Identifies that vehicle safety improvements mainly protect occupants
Considers changes in travel patterns/exposure
Analyses infrastructure and vehicle design factors
Shows understanding of how different road users have different risk profiles

evaluate.question: Evaluate whether lowering the speed limit in residential areas from 50km/h to 30km/h would be an effective road safety measure. Consider evidence, benefits, costs, and implementation challenges.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate comprehensively. Evidence: pedestrian survival rates dramatically higher at 30km/h vs 50km/h. Benefits: reduced severity of any crash, possibly reduced crash rates, more pleasant streets for walking/cycling. Costs: longer travel times, driver frustration. Implementation: enforcement challenges, community resistance. Strong responses use evidence to reach a balanced conclusion and may consider how to address implementation challenges.
successCriteria: Uses evidence about speed and crash severity
Considers benefits beyond just safety
Acknowledges practical implementation challenges
Reaches a reasoned evaluation with justification

create.question: Design an advocacy campaign to improve road safety for a specific vulnerable road user group in your local area. Include the issue, evidence, proposed solutions, target audience, and campaign strategies.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students design a comprehensive advocacy campaign. Should include: specific issue identified (e.g., cyclist safety on a particular route), evidence of the problem (crash data, community concerns), evidence-based solutions, clear target audience (local council, VicRoads), and realistic campaign strategies (petition, media, council meetings). Campaign should demonstrate understanding of how decisions are made and how to influence them.
successCriteria: Identifies a specific, genuine issue
Includes evidence supporting the need for change
Proposes practical, evidence-based solutions
Targets appropriate decision-makers
Outlines realistic campaign strategies

unistructural.modelResponse: Vulnerable road users are those at higher risk of injury, including pedestrians, cyclists, and motorcyclists, because they lack the protection of a vehicle cabin.
unistructural.rubric: Correctly defines vulnerable road users as those with higher injury risk due to lack of vehicle protection.

multistructural.stem: List four interventions that have reduced Australia's road toll over the past 50 years.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four interventions that have reduced Australia's road toll are: 1) Mandatory seatbelt laws, 2) Random breath testing for drink driving, 3) Improved vehicle safety standards (crumple zones, airbags), 4) Speed cameras and enforcement.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant interventions such as seatbelts, drink-driving enforcement, vehicle safety, speed enforcement, GLS, road improvements, or campaigns.

relational.stem: Explain how the interests of different road users (drivers, cyclists, pedestrians, businesses) can conflict, and how the Safe System approach helps navigate these conflicts.
relational.modelResponse: Different road users have conflicting interests. Drivers want fast, direct travel; cyclists want safe, separated paths; pedestrians want easy crossing and slow traffic; businesses want parking and delivery access. Space is limited, so gains for one group often come at others' expense. The Safe System approach helps by establishing a shared principle: no road death is acceptable. This provides an ethical basis for decisions. Speed reduction might inconvenience drivers but prevents pedestrian deaths - the Safe System says this trade-off is clear. Separated cycle lanes might remove parking but enable safe cycling - again, life trumps convenience. By centering safety, the approach provides a framework for resolving conflicts, though trade-offs remain politically contested.
relational.rubric: Identifies genuine conflicts between road user groups. Explains how Safe System provides an ethical framework. Shows understanding of how safety can guide trade-offs. Acknowledges that conflicts remain challenging.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how climate change and urbanisation might affect road safety priorities and policies over the next 20 years. What shifts might be needed?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Climate change and urbanisation will reshape road safety priorities. Climate impacts: extreme weather events will make roads more dangerous; heat may affect road surfaces and driver comfort; more frequent disasters may damage infrastructure. Policy shift needed toward climate-resilient roads. Urbanisation impacts: denser cities may need more focus on walking/cycling safety and less on highway crashes. Mode shift toward active transport requires serious investment in safe infrastructure for vulnerable users. This is a shift from car-centric safety to people-centric mobility safety. Urbanisation also means more conflict points between modes. Speed limits may need to decrease in urban areas. Electric and autonomous vehicles add complexity. Planning may need to integrate transport safety with climate adaptation and urban design. The Safe System approach provides a framework, but priorities within it may shift significantly.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies specific impacts of climate change and urbanisation on transport. Proposes meaningful policy shifts needed. Shows sophisticated understanding of interconnected factors. Considers how Safe System approach might evolve.

reflectionQuestions: What local road safety issues have you noticed that might be worth advocating about?
How does understanding road safety data change your perspective on crashes?

I can evaluate road safety policies using multiple criteria
I can develop advocacy strategies for transport safety improvements
studentReflection.connectionToLife: Understanding road safety at a systems level prepares you for informed citizenship and potential careers in transport, planning, or policy. Advocacy skills developed now can lead to real improvements in your community.

E.title: Road and Transport Safety - Extension
E.levelDescription: Students working 2+ years above the expected level will synthesise research on road safety, evaluate international approaches, and design innovative strategies addressing emerging transport challenges.
E.contentAdaptations: Engages with academic research, international comparisons, emerging technologies, and complex policy analysis. Encourages original thinking about future transport safety challenges.
learningIntentions: I am learning to synthesise research on road trauma causation and prevention
I am learning to evaluate international approaches to road safety
I am learning to design innovative solutions for emerging transport challenges
successCriteria: I can synthesise research to explain complex factors affecting road safety outcomes
I can evaluate international approaches using effectiveness and equity criteria
I can design innovative solutions addressing emerging transport challenges
prerequisites: Advanced understanding of road safety systems and policies
Knowledge of Safe System and Vision Zero approaches

vocabularyTerms.definition: How well a country or region performs on road safety outcomes, often measured in deaths per 100,000 population
Systematic comparison of benefits and costs of policies, including the value placed on preventing deaths and injuries
The economic value used in policy analysis for preventing one death, derived from willingness-to-pay studies
What would have happened in the absence of an intervention, used to estimate policy effects
Road design approach minimising segregation and traffic controls, relying on human interaction
Integrated transport platforms combining various modes in a single service
The challenge of connecting people from transport hubs to their final destinations
Fair distribution of transport benefits and burdens across population groups

contentSections.title: International Road Safety Performance
contentSections.content: Countries have vastly different road safety outcomes. Norway and Sweden achieve around 2 deaths per 100,000 population, while global average is around 18. High-performing countries share characteristics: strong political commitment, systematic approach, evidence-based policy, and sustained investment. Australia performs in the middle of high-income countries (around 5/100,000), with room for improvement. International comparison helps identify effective interventions, but context matters - what works in Sweden may need adaptation for Australian conditions (distances, climate, settlement patterns).

contentSections.title: Research on Road Trauma Causation
contentSections.content: Research identifies complex causation of road trauma. The Haddon Matrix analyses factors in pre-crash (what causes crashes), crash (what determines injury severity), and post-crash (what affects outcomes after injury) phases, across human, vehicle, and environment dimensions. Research shows interactions between factors - fatigue plus alcohol has multiplicative effects. Social determinants affect safety - lower socioeconomic areas often have higher crash rates. Medical research shows even 'minor' crashes can cause lasting harm. Understanding causation complexity informs better policy by targeting multiple factors simultaneously.

contentSections.title: Emerging Transport Technologies
contentSections.content: Transport technology is changing rapidly. Autonomous vehicles promise to eliminate human error but raise new challenges (liability, security, ethics of crash algorithms, employment impacts). Electric vehicles require rethinking charging infrastructure and emergency response. E-scooters and e-bikes have expanded rapidly, often before regulations caught up. Mobility as a Service integrates modes but creates data privacy questions. Each technology brings potential safety benefits and new risks. Policy must adapt to technology faster than traditional processes allow while applying precautionary principles.

contentSections.title: Transport Equity and Safety
contentSections.content: Road safety and equity intersect in multiple ways. Disadvantaged areas often have worse infrastructure and higher crash rates. People without car access may face more exposure as pedestrians on dangerous roads. Indigenous Australians have much higher road death rates. Older people and children are more vulnerable as pedestrians. People with disabilities face specific challenges. Vision Zero and the Safe System include equity - everyone deserves safety - but implementation often prioritises areas with more political voice. Genuine equity requires directing resources to where needs are greatest, not where advocacy is strongest.

remember.question: What are the three phases of the Haddon Matrix?

options.text: Human, Vehicle, Environment
options.feedback: These are the three factors/columns, not the three phases.

options.text: Pre-crash, Crash, Post-crash
options.feedback: Correct! The Haddon Matrix analyses factors across these three phases.

options.text: Before, During, After
options.feedback: While similar in meaning, the correct terms are pre-crash, crash, and post-crash.

options.text: Road, Speed, Vehicle
options.feedback: These relate to Safe System pillars, not Haddon Matrix phases.

understand.question: Why might 'value of statistical life' be a useful but controversial concept in road safety policy?

options.text: Because some lives are worth more than others
options.feedback: VSL doesn't suggest some lives are worth more - it's applied equally to estimate policy benefits.

options.text: Because it allows cost-benefit analysis of safety investments, but puts a dollar value on human life which is ethically uncomfortable
options.feedback: Correct! VSL enables systematic policy analysis but commodifying life raises genuine ethical concerns.

options.text: Because statistics aren't accurate
options.feedback: The controversy isn't about statistical accuracy but about valuing life in monetary terms.

options.text: Because the government doesn't want to spend money on safety
options.feedback: VSL is actually used to justify spending on safety by quantifying benefits.

apply.question: A city is considering allowing e-scooters on roads and paths. Apply principles from road safety research to suggest a policy framework.

options.text: Ban them completely as they're too dangerous
options.feedback: Blanket bans don't allow for potential benefits. A risk-managed approach is better.

options.text: Allow them anywhere with no restrictions
options.feedback: This doesn't apply safety principles - speed and infrastructure matching are needed.

options.text: Apply Safe System principles: regulate speed, require helmets, define where they can be used based on infrastructure, collect data to monitor outcomes
options.feedback: Correct! This applies multiple Safe System elements while allowing the technology's benefits.

options.text: Wait to see what other cities do first
options.feedback: While learning from others is useful, policy should be proactive, not only reactive.

analyse.question: Analyse why Australia's road safety performance has stalled in recent years after decades of improvement.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple factors. Easy wins (seatbelts, drink-driving) have been achieved; remaining problems are harder. Vehicle safety improvements continue but are offset by factors like distraction, drug driving, ageing fleet in some areas. Infrastructure investment hasn't kept pace. SUV popularity increases pedestrian injury severity. Travel growth increases exposure. Political will may have reduced. Some countermeasures (like speed enforcement) face public resistance. Strong responses connect factors and consider what would be needed to restart progress.
successCriteria: Identifies that early interventions have been implemented
Analyses newer challenges (distraction, drugs, SUVs)
Considers infrastructure and investment factors
Shows understanding of why progress stalls despite known solutions

evaluate.question: Evaluate whether the principle 'no level of road deaths is acceptable' (from Vision Zero) is a realistic or useful policy goal compared to 'reducing road deaths'.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate both positions. Zero death target: provides clear ethical position, prevents accepting any death as inevitable, drives ambitious action, but may be literally unachievable with current technology. 'Reduction' target: more realistic, allows cost-benefit trade-offs, but may accept preventable deaths. Evaluation might consider: whether aiming for zero drives better outcomes even if not achieved; whether accepting any deaths is morally justifiable; how targets affect resource allocation and political will. Strong responses engage with the philosophical and practical dimensions.
successCriteria: Engages seriously with both positions
Considers practical and ethical dimensions
Evaluates how different targets affect action
Reaches a reasoned position with justification

create.question: Design an innovative approach to improving road safety for vulnerable road users in an Australian city, incorporating emerging technologies, evidence-based interventions, and equity considerations.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students design a comprehensive approach. Should include: analysis of current vulnerable road user safety issues, evidence-based interventions from research, appropriate use of emerging technologies (with limitations acknowledged), consideration of equity (which communities benefit, who might be excluded), implementation pathway, and evaluation approach. Design should demonstrate synthesis of research, innovation, and practical considerations.
successCriteria: Analyses current safety issues for vulnerable users
Incorporates evidence-based interventions
Uses emerging technologies appropriately
Addresses equity considerations explicitly
Includes implementation and evaluation planning

unistructural.stem: What is the Haddon Matrix used for in road safety research?
unistructural.modelResponse: The Haddon Matrix is used to analyse factors contributing to road crashes across human, vehicle, and environment dimensions, in pre-crash, crash, and post-crash phases.
unistructural.rubric: Correctly identifies the Haddon Matrix as a framework for analysing crash causation across multiple dimensions and phases.

multistructural.stem: List four characteristics that high-performing countries (like Sweden and Norway) share in their road safety approaches.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four characteristics of high-performing road safety countries are: 1) Strong political commitment to Vision Zero, 2) Systematic Safe System approach, 3) Evidence-based policy making, 4) Sustained investment in road safety measures.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant characteristics such as political commitment, systematic approach, evidence-based policy, investment, enforcement, or infrastructure quality.

relational.stem: Explain how social determinants of health connect to road safety outcomes.
relational.modelResponse: Social determinants affect road safety through multiple pathways. People in disadvantaged areas often have: poorer quality roads and infrastructure, less investment in safety measures, greater exposure as pedestrians when they can't afford cars, older vehicles with fewer safety features, jobs requiring long commutes or night work (fatigue risk), and less access to safety information. Indigenous Australians face higher road death rates due to remoteness, poorer roads, older vehicles, and barriers to healthcare after crashes. These patterns show that road trauma, like other health outcomes, is not equally distributed - it follows social gradients. Addressing road safety equity requires directing resources to those at highest risk, not just those with political voice.
relational.rubric: Identifies multiple pathways connecting disadvantage to road safety. Shows understanding that road trauma follows social patterns. Connects to equity implications for policy.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how the introduction of fully autonomous vehicles might transform both the benefits and the risks of transport, and what governance frameworks might be needed.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Fully autonomous vehicles could transform transport safety by eliminating human error, which contributes to most crashes. Benefits include: no fatigue, distraction, impairment, or emotional driving; consistent rule following; ability to communicate with other vehicles. Risks include: cybersecurity vulnerabilities could be catastrophic; software errors could affect all vehicles simultaneously; transition period with mixed human/AV traffic is complex; ethical dilemmas in crash scenarios; job displacement affects transport workers; technology may not handle all conditions. Governance frameworks needed include: liability frameworks (who is responsible when AV crashes?); safety certification requirements; cybersecurity standards; data privacy regulations; rules for human/AV mixed traffic; urban planning for changed transport patterns; just transition for affected workers; ethical guidelines for programming. International coordination is essential as technology crosses borders. We're essentially designing a new transport system - getting governance right is as important as getting technology right.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies substantial benefits and meaningful risks of AVs. Proposes multiple governance frameworks needed. Shows sophisticated understanding of systemic change. Considers equity and transition issues.
